thread.title: Family fun time: Cruise activities kids will love
thread.title_full: Family fun time: Cruise activities kids will love

title: Family fun time: Cruise activities kids will love
text:
If you're looking for a little togetherness time, outside of the playrooms are a host of other things you and your kids can do together for a bonding experience at sea. Getty Images Fullscreen Memorable times with your kids can be as simple as exploring. You're on a big ship and there are things to discover. Grab a deck map and take the kids on a tour. Celebrity Cruises Fullscreen You can even make a game of it – spot the smokestack, map the lifeboats, guess where the cameras are that show the live views on your stateroom TV. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen Free ice cream whenever you want from self-serve, soft-serve machines on the Lido deck is a cruise ship favorite on lines including Carnival Cruise Line. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen On Disney Cruise Line ships the chocolate-coated Mickey Mouse ear-shaped ice cream bars are the desirable confection – and even available via room service. Disney Cruise Line Fullscreen Your kids can have as much bacon as you let them at breakfast, can eat pizza at all hours and can sample as many dishes as they want at dinner (ordering from kiddie or adult menus). Quentin Bacon, Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen Your kids may even surprise you by trying stuff at onboard restaurants they might turn their noses up to at home. Tim Bieber, Celebrity Cruises Fullscreen Swimming is always a great bonding opportunity for families. Newer ships may have a kiddie splash pool or even a whole splash area with squirting walls and dump buckets and such. Steve Beaudet, Norwegian Cruise Line Fullscreen Even if there aren't specialized areas, there will certainly be a main pool that's a magnet for families. You'll need to carefully read the rules in terms of keeping your children supervised. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen It's important to note that while Disney has lifeguards onboard, most cruise lines do not; shipboard pools are a place you'll need to carefully watch your kids. Jimmy DeFlippo, Disney Cruise Line Fullscreen Squeals of delight can be heard from youngsters on Carnival's signature Twister slides and in the waterslides in the extensive Aqua Parks on the newest Norwegian Cruise Line ships. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen On the Disney Fantasy and Disney Dream, you can do an exhilarating, wet parent-child experience sharing a raft on the 765-foot AquaDuck watercoaster. Kent Phillips, Disney Cruise Line Fullscreen A word of warning for parents: The watercoaster rides are so fun that the kids (and you!) will want to do these experiences again and again. Todd Anderson, Disney Cruise Line Fullscreen Hang out with the kids at a complimentary movie. Royal Caribbean, on ships including Anthem of the Seas, screens first-run DreamWorks movies and Disney shows Disney and Pixar productions. Michel Verdure, Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen Your kids will also enjoy the shipboard equivalent to drive-in movies, watching on a big screen outdoors, including on Movies Under the Stars screens on Princess Cruises ships. Princess Cruises Fullscreen The Carnival Vista, debuting in the spring, will have the first IMAX theater at sea. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen Try your hand at something your kids are interested in. Video games are so popular with kids at Club HAL on Holland America Line ships the line has time limits on play. Peter Knego Fullscreen If you want the family to take in the fresh sea air, hit the basketball court or shuffleboard courts or Ping-Pong tables or mini-golf course for outdoor fun. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen But the fun is not restricted to the kids' center – many ships have game centers/arcades filled with the latest and greatest where you can challenge junior to a virtual shootout or game of air hockey. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen Kids may be shy at first but the room stewards and dining room servers on big ships are experienced in dealing with passengers of all ages. Merlyn Parola, 42, is from the Philippines, and is a 15-year Carnival veteran currently on the Carnival Fascination. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen There will be treats and much pampering and attention paid to your progeny. Don't be surprised if your kids even learn a few words in the native language of their favorite crew member. Galyna Berzina, 39, is from the Ukraine and has been with Carnival for 10 years. Carnival Cruise Line Fullscreen Towel animal creations, a nightly treat prepared by your cabin steward, are a source of fascination for youngsters. Here, Classic towel elephant on a Holland America ship. Fran Golden Fullscreen On Carnival ships, don't miss the towel animal parade one morning at the pool (you can also purchase a book to learn how to make the creations at home). Fran Golden Fullscreen Each cruise line offers unique activities for families. For instance, you may find opportunities to mingle with costumed characters (Disney, Royal Caribbean, Carnival). Matt Stroshane, Disney Cruise Line Fullscreen Your ship may offer wow features and activities like ice-skating (Royal Caribbean), bowling (Norwegian), rock-climbing and more. Specific options vary by line and ship, so check in advance for this sort of family fun. Royal Caribbean International Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide 4 CONNECT 26 TWEET 4 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE One reason big ships work so well for family vacations is there are complimentary kids' programs. Counselors occupy youngsters with activities such as arts and crafts, storytelling, games and contests in well-equipped playrooms while parents get time off to do such rare things as relax with a good book on a lounge chair.
But if you're looking for a little togetherness time, outside of the playrooms are a host of other things you and your kids can do together for a bonding experience at sea. Here are 10 shipboard activities your kids will love.
Exploring: Memorable times with your kids can be as simple as exploring. You're on a big ship and there are things to discover. Grab a deck map and take the kids on a tour. You can even make a game of it – spot the smokestack, map the lifeboats, guess where the cameras are that show the live views on your stateroom TV.
Eating ice cream: Free ice cream whenever you want from self-serve, soft-serve machines on the Lido deck is a cruise ship favorite on lines including Carnival Cruise Line. On Disney Cruise Line ships the chocolate-coated Mickey Mouse ear-shaped ice cream bars are the desirable confection – and even available via room service.
Dining: Your kids can have as much bacon as you let them at breakfast, can eat pizza at all hours and can sample as many dishes as they want at dinner (ordering from kiddie or adult menus). They may even surprise you by trying stuff they might turn their noses up to at home.
Swimming: Newer ships may have a kiddie splash pool or even a whole splash area with squirting walls and dump buckets and such. There will certainly be a main pool that's a magnet for families. You'll need to carefully read the rules in terms of keeping your children supervised. Note: While Disney has lifeguards onboard, most cruise lines do not; shipboard pools are a place you'll need to carefully watch your kids.
Doing waterslides/watercoaster: . Squeals of delight can be heard from youngsters on Carnival's signature Twister slides and in the waterslides in the extensive Aqua Parks on the newest Norwegian Cruise Line ships. On the Disney Fantasy and Disney Dream, you can do an exhilarating, wet parent-child experience sharing a raft on the 765-foot AquaDuck watercoaster. Warning: The kids will want to do these experiences again and again.
Seeing movies: Hang out with the kids at a complimentary movie. Royal Caribbean, on ships including Anthem of the Seas, screens first-run DreamWorks movies and Disney shows Disney and Pixar productions. Your kids will also enjoy the shipboard equivalent to drive-in movies, watching on a big screen outdoors, including on Movies Under the Stars screens on Princess Cruises ships. The Carnival Vista, debuting in the spring, will have the first IMAX theater at sea.
Playing games: Video games are so popular with kids at Club HAL on Holland America Line ships the line has time limits on play. But the fun is not restricted to the kids' center – many ships have game centers/arcades filled with the latest and greatest where you can challenge junior to a virtual shootout or game of air hockey. Or hit the basketball court or shuffleboard courts or Ping-Pong tables or mini-golf course for outdoor fun.
Meeting the crew: Kids may be shy at first but the room stewards and dining room servers on big ships are experienced in dealing with passengers of all ages. There will be treats and much pampering and attention paid to your progeny. Don't be surprised if your kids even learn a few words in the native language of their favorite crew member.
Hugging towel animals: Towel animal creations, a nightly treat prepared by your cabin steward, are a source of fascination for youngsters. On Carnival ships, don't miss the towel animal parade one morning at the pool (you can also purchase a book to learn how to make the creations at home).
Sampling accouterments: You may find opportunities to mingle with costumed characters (Disney, Royal Caribbean, Carnival), do such activities as ice-skating (Royal Caribbean), bowling (Norwegian), rock-climbing and more. Specific options vary by line and ship, so check in advance for this sort of family fun.
